metadata.synopsis: Wyll's Romance scene in Act 3. Wyll invited the player to a romantic talk near the banks fo the chionthar.
metadata.how_to_trigger: - Use debug book (go to WYR, recruit wyll, use origin debug book to setup the romance scene, long rest, find and talk to wyll in camp)- Be in relationship with wyll, Save/don't save Ravengard in Iron Throne, return from Iron Throne, trigger a camp night.

2.speaker: Wyll
2.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player approaches Wyll. He is contemplative.

129.speaker: Wyll
129.text: As the Blade, I've faced untold brutes and beasts. Together we've seen illithid horrors most souls could merely fathom.

118.speaker: Wyll
118.text: I live at the mercy of fiends. A man with the horrid face of a devil, awaiting his future in Hells' blistered army.

110.speaker: Wyll
110.text: I live at the mercy of fiends. A devil's plaything awaiting a future in the Hells.

6.speaker: Wyll
6.text: I've lived at the mercy of fiends - a devil's plaything trying to right the Coast's wrong.

27.speaker: Wyll
27.text: But I've only now come to see who my true enemy's been.

38.speaker: Wyll
38.text: Maybe. But I think the right answer is much simpler than that:

134.speaker: Wyll
134.text: Time is so godsdamned greedy. It races forward no matter how hard we rail against it.

95.speaker: Wyll
95.text: Not so long ago, I was dreaming of our own personal forever, endless nights in each other's arms.

12.speaker: Wyll
12.text: But time caught up with me. Father is dead. Baldur's Gate nears its ruin. My one and only duty must be to the city.

142.speaker: Wyll
142.text: Forever could only be a dream.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: I understand. The city needs you, and I'd only be getting in the way.

149.speaker: Wyll
149.text: Quite the opposite. I'd be getting in yours.

151.speaker: Player
151.text: We can still have it, Wyll. We can defeat the Brain and be together.

121.speaker: Wyll
121.text: One monster slain, then. And another after that, and then another. There will always be one more evil to fell.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: So this is a break-up? I should've known, after all I've given you.

105.speaker: Wyll
105.text: And none of it shall go to waste, you have my solemn promise. But - truth be told, it's not just Baldur's Gate I'm protecting.

136.speaker: Wyll
136.text: My father taught me more lessons than I can count. But perhaps the greatest one is this: a champion's heart's as sharp as a new blade.

73.speaker: Wyll
73.text: Pull me too close, and I'm destined to hurt you.

16.speaker: Wyll
16.text: I was thinking - how about one last dance. For old times' sake?

68.speaker: Player
68.text: You mean so much to me. I can feel my heart bleeding.

98.speaker: Wyll
98.text: Maybe I can staunch it. Just - for a moment.

164.speaker: Wyll
164.text: One last dance, for old times' sake.

80.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Wyll and the player bow to each other, and then slowly begin to dance. This one is sadder than before. The camer pans upwards as the dance continues, and the scene fades away.

JLatino: Reuse dance anims, slow them down, fade to black as dance starts

145.context:
CinematicNodeContext: Wyll and the player bow to each other, and then slowly begin to dance. This one is sadder than before. The camer pans upwards as the dance continues, and the scene fades away.

Short player branch

JLatino: Reuse dance anims, slow them down, fade to black as dance starts

83.speaker: Player
83.text: You break up with me and then ask to dance? That's some godsdamned nerve.

5.speaker: Wyll
5.text: I deserve that. And I'm sorry.

56.speaker: Wyll
56.text: I'll leave you to your thoughts. I hope somewhere in them, you find peace.

36.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll walks away, leaving the player standing there. The camera pans up, then the scene fades.

144.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player walks away. The camera shows Wyll standing there. He closes his eyes and the scene fades.

33.speaker: Wyll
33.text: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take. My eternal soul is at its mercy.

7.speaker: Wyll
7.text: It builds mountains and deserts, only to tear them asunder. It fells armies, it conquers kings, queens - even gods.

15.speaker: Wyll
15.text: We blink, and we're gone. And our hopes, our memories, our heart-bonds are gone with us.

51.speaker: Wyll
51.text: It even comes for your people in the astral sea. Time may hunt slowly - but it still hunts.

89.speaker: Wyll
89.text: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop it -

34.speaker: Wyll
34.context: CinematicNodeContext: (SCENE) Wyll reaches out his hand in front of him, to the player, at the end of the line.

53.speaker: Player
53.text: I can't take your hand without hurting you, but I'll follow where you lead.

141.context: CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright. NOTE: Karlach CANNOT take Wyll's hand, they shouldn't be touching.See N41

150.speaker: Player
150.text: All right. But this better be worth it.

70.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player takes Wyll's right hand with their left. Wyll smiles and the scene fades out.

81.context: CinematicNodeContext: The scene fades back in. Wyll and the player are near the Chionthar, and walk towards a towering and impressive tree. Acorns are scattered underneath it. It is a beautiful night; the moon and stars shine bright.

111.speaker: Wyll
111.text: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.

93.speaker: Wyll
93.text: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.

157.speaker: Wyll
157.text: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.

78.speaker: Wyll
78.text: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.

18.context: CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves from the two of you and outwards. A vista of stunning and quiet beauty.

116.speaker: Player
116.text: Enjoy the view. Enjoy Wyll's quiet company.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: A beautiful story. I'm glad you told it to me.

42.speaker: Wyll
42.text: I was hoping you'd think so.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: I'm not sure I can see into forever. But it's still a nice view.

0.speaker: Wyll
0.text: My favourite in all of the Coast. All of Faerûn, even. Not even the Sea of Stars could rival its magnificence -

92.speaker: Player
92.text: Seriously? You dragged me out here to look at a tree?

23.speaker: Wyll
23.text: I did. But also to see something else:

109.speaker: Wyll
109.text: I've been thinking a lot about forever. Moreso, I've been thinking everything that comes before -

17.speaker: Wyll
17.text: And who I want at my side as it passes.

131.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll kneels to the ground. He takes an acorn and holds it in the palm of his hands, but keeps them close to his body.

79.speaker: Wyll
79.text: My mother always said the Wilden Oak's acorns held just a touch of wishing magic.

107.speaker: Wyll
107.text: If that be so, then may my greatest wish come true tonight:
107.context: CinematicNodeContext: (SCENE) At the end of the line, Wyll holds his hands out to you, with the acorn held in them.

74.speaker: Wyll
74.text: I love you. Will you be mine - today, and tomorrow, and reaching into eternity?

35.speaker: Wyll
35.text: Gods. You've made me the happiest soul in all the Realms.

32.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player takes the acorn from Wyll's hands. He smiles, but remains kneeling.

120.speaker: Narrator
120.text: *Your skin flushes and your soul sings as you palm the acorn. Wishing magic, affection, love - whatever the cause, it's as real as the ground beneath you.*

76.speaker: Wyll
76.text: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!

101.speaker: Player
101.text: Join Wyll in the grass. Give yourself to him completely.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: Shit, yes. Let's see the snake this devil's been hiding.

67.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll, still kneeling, pulls the player to the ground and they start kissing intensely.

153.context: CinematicNodeContext: They roll about under the tree as the camera pans upwards, showing the beautiful night once more, as the happy couple begin to make love under the comfort of the Wilding Oak. (Use all the cinematic discretion you like!) The scene then fades away.

66.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll, still kneeling, pulls the player to the ground and they start kissing intensely.

133.context: CinematicNodeContext: They roll about under the tree as the camera pans upwards, showing the beautiful night once more, as the happy couple begin to make love under the comfort of the Wilding Oak. (Use all the cinematic discretion you like!) The scene then fades away.

125.speaker: Player
125.text: It's about time. Let's see what the Blade can do with his weapon.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: Not yet, Wyll. Not 'til all this trouble is behind us.

46.speaker: Wyll
46.text: I understand, truly. All I need is you. The rest is just details.

39.speaker: Wyll
39.text: For now, let's enjoy this piece of eternity.

102.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll pulls the player to the ground. They sit, holding hands, as the camera pans up, showing the beautiful landscape ahead of our lovers.

24.speaker: Wyll
24.text: Get down here, already. It's time we started our happily-ever-after!

11.speaker: Wyll
11.text: Sit with me. It's time we started our happily-ever-after.
11.context: CinematicNodeContext: Karlach sits next to Wyll, an intimate but safe distance. They talk all night.NodeContext: Joyously

77.speaker: Player
77.text: I'm not sure. It's a lot to take in.

3.speaker: Wyll
3.text: It is. I swear, I've lived a thousand lives since I've known you.

163.speaker: Wyll
163.text: But I'm ready to live a thousand more, if you can bear me.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: Yes. I want to be with you, for as long as you'll have me.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: I don't want a commitment. But I'd welcome a good roll in the hay.

100.speaker: Wyll
100.text: Ours is such a beautiful story, and this isn't the ending I wanted to write.

63.speaker: Wyll
63.text: But - I can't resist you. I'd sooner know one unforgettable night than a lifetime of 'what ifs'.

64.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll casts aside the acorn and holds his hand to the player.

146.speaker: Wyll
146.text: Gods, I want you. But I can't take your body without taking your heart.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: I don't want a commitment. But I'd welcome a good roll in the hay.

124.speaker: Wyll
124.text: I - I understand. All the more fool am I for pressing my fortunes.
124.context: CinematicNodeContext: (SCENE) Wyll stands up at end of the line, still holding the acorn.

104.speaker: Wyll
104.context: CinematicNodeContext: (SCENE) Wyll hands you the acorn at the end of the line.

9.speaker: Narrator
9.text: *Your stomach falls briefly as the acorn touches your hand. You shiver with melancholy - and hope.*

75.speaker: Wyll
75.text: May you be granted every wish you ask for. You deserve each and every one.

72.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll walks away, leaving the player holding the acorn in their hand. The camera pans upwards showing the gorgeous night sky.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: I can't give you forever, Wyll. But I can give you tonight.

127.speaker: Player
127.text: Oh gods, no. You've got the wrong idea about all this.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Gods, no. Have you looked at yourself? You're hideous.

59.speaker: Wyll
59.text: All this time, and that's still what you see?

84.speaker: Wyll
84.text: The Wilden Oak. Legend has it it's stood since the Age of Dawn.

65.speaker: Wyll
65.text: I used to come here and climb it when father's eye was turned elsewhere - daydream of the stories it might tell, if I listened close enough.

55.speaker: Wyll
55.text: The dragon lords sparking the skies above it. The moon elves first plucking the strings of the Weave.

132.speaker: Wyll
132.text: Standing here, I feel like I can see into forever.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: All right. But this better be worth it.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: We've got big problems to solve, Wyll. Maybe later.

40.speaker: Wyll
40.text: A toll of the bell - it's all I ask. Our problems can wait that long.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: I couldn't have said it better. Let's go.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: Sorry, but a 'no' will have to do.

14.speaker: Wyll
14.text: Understood. Your will is strong, and I would have it no other way.
14.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll withdraws his handNodeContext: Disappointed, holding back his sdaness.

139.speaker: Wyll
139.text: Dance. And when you do, think of me.
139.context: CinematicNodeContext: Wyll turns and walks away, leaving you alone.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: Dance. Remember your precious moment with Wyll.

154.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player dances, mimicking the moves Wyll made in the second romance night. The scene fades.

126.context: CinematicNodeContext: The camera moves upwards, showing the player from above, then fades away.

155.speaker: Wyll
155.text: Lucky for us, I've found a way to stop time -

69.speaker: Wyll
69.text: Time is so gods-damned greedy. It can never give, only take.

71.speaker: Wyll
71.text: So you'd think. But the right answer is much simpler than that:

37.speaker: Player
37.text: The poignant tedium of your story?

57.speaker: Wyll
57.text: I'd like to think not. The answer is much simpler than that:

4.speaker: Player
4.text: How is this a question? The answer is Mizora. It's always been Mizora.
